column4: Hi. I installed ubuntu along with windows 7, but now since I'm more focused on learning true linux (commands and stuff), instead of a new distribution, I decided to virtualize another distribution of linux. the thing is, currently the grub has control over the MBR... and the only way I know of removing ubuntu is  by deleting its partitions, but that will leave me with a MBR pointing nowhere thus leaving me unable to boot windows 7. I was wondering what

i don't know with Windows7. but with XP, you'd do something like insert the disk and get to where it ask you for a partition to install to, you select it, then cancel the install, and that would put a windows boot loader back into the mbr
